channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Jetliner Explodes Over Ukraine; Struck by Missile, Officials Say
item.description: Malaysia Airlines 17, which was carrying 298 people onboard, was shot down by a surface-to-air missile that might be Russian made, American officials said.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE, ERIC SCHMITT and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: The fiery crash left debris strewn across several square miles in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine, near the Russian border.

item.title: Earlier Downing of Transport Plane Over Ukraine Foreshadowed Tragedy
item.description: Three days before the downing of a Malaysian civilian airliner, a Ukrainian transport plane was shot down by a surface-to-air missile while flying at 21,000 feet.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, MARK MAZZETTI and C.J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: A woman at Kuala Lumpur International Airport reacted to the news that a Malaysia Airlines plane had crashed in Ukraine.

item.title: Israeli Military Invades Gaza, With Sights Set on Hamas Operations
item.description: Israel said it would target tunnels that can infiltrate its territory after cease-fire talks failed to de-escalate the air war that has raged for 10 days.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers near the Gaza Strip on Thursday. Israel’s assault came in answer to an attack by militants through a tunnel.

item.title: Tragedy on Top of Crisis May Strengthen Stand Against Russia in U.S. and Europe
item.description: If the Malaysia Airlines jet was downed by pro-Russian separatists, it will reinforce the United States’ urging for a stronger stance against Moscow.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: A girl placed flowers at the Netherlands Embassy in Kiev, Ukraine, on Thursday after the crash of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, which was en route from Amsterdam.

item.title: World Briefing: Tunisia: Militants Hit Soldiers in Deadly Attack
item.description: An extremist group believed linked to Al Qaeda’s North Africa arm claimed responsibility for the attack that killed at least 14 soldiers, the authorities said Thursday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: Ex-Lawmaker Charged in Child Pornography Case
item.description: Sebastian Edathy has been charged with possessing pornographic photos and videos of children.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Malaysia Airlines Plane Leaves Trail of Debris
item.description: Local residents and rescue workers saw smoldering debris litter miles of sparsely populated Ukrainian farmland after Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crashed.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: American Spy Chief Leaves
item.description: The United States’ top spy in Germany has left the country, the American Embassy in Berlin said Thursday, a week after Germany demanded that the C.I.A.’s Berlin station chief leave.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Air Disaster Strains Moscow’s Competing Strategy on Ukrainian Rebels
item.description: The Kremlin’s double game in Ukraine — publicly endorsing peace talks while secretly supporting the separatists — appeared less crafty than disastrous after the downing of a Malaysian jet.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: Fraud Case Against Senator
item.description: The police have charged Mike Duffy, a suspended Conservative senator who was once a close ally of Prime Minister Stephen Harper, with 31 counts of fraud, breach of trust and bribery.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Egypt Cuts Tax Breaks for Fuel; Few Protest
item.description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi has called for a drastic cut to energy subsidies in order to decrease the country’s budget deficit, but critics say the initiative will harm vulnerable citizens.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: “Work hard and bear with me,” President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi told Egyptians.

item.title: Terror Group Back on the Offensive in Afghanistan
item.description: Militants fired volleys of rocket-propelled grenades at Kabul’s airport Thursday morning after seizing control of a building nearby.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An officer searched for evidence on Thursday after a suicide bombing at Kabul airport. Attackers killed a guard and were killed themselves in a battle with security forces, Afghan officials said.

item.title: From Gaza, an Array of Makeshift Rockets Packs a Counterpunch
item.description: Though the crude rockets smuggled via ship and tunnel from Iran, Libya, Sudan and Syria rarely hit high-value targets, they are reaching farther into Israel than ever before.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Plumes of smoke above a neighborhood in Gaza City after militants fired rockets toward Israel on Thursday after a lull in fighting.

item.title: Gorgona Journal: Prisoners in Gorgona Learn the Art of Winemaking
item.description: In an Italian penal colony, inmates work to produce wine in a new approach to incarceration that aims to provide skills for life after release.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two inmates, Santo Scianguetta, left, and Umberto Prinzi, in the vineyard in Gorgona, Italy. Mr. Scianguetta said the experience of working there was building his confidence.

item.title: Cleaning Up Varanasi Is a Test for Narendra Modi
item.description: The new prime minister has promised to tackle Varanasi’s many problems and to turn the downtrodden city into a showcase of culture and small business.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHANIE STROM

item.title: Australia Tax Repeal Is Big Blow to Fight Against Emissions
item.description: A repeal of laws requiring big companies to pay for carbon emissions will complicate plans to knit together markets for trading emission allowances.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS, STANLEY REED and CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:description: Steel works looming over homes in Port Kembla, south of Sydney, Australia. The country is among the world’s biggest producers of carbon emissions on a per capita basis.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Gaza and Israel: The Road to War, Paved by the West
item.description: By preventing payment of Hamas workers’ salaries and free passage to Egypt, Israel and the West laid the groundwork for the latest escalation.
item.dc:creator: By NATHAN THRALL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Bill Porter on Journeys, Poets and Best-Sellerdom in China
item.description: Bill Porter has been one of the most prolific translators of Chinese texts, while also developing into a travel writer with a cult following. In an interview, he discusses his works and his plans.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON
item.media:description: Bill Porter is a best-selling author who has also translated over a dozen books of poetry and religious texts.

item.title: Palestinian Youth Who Was Abducted and Killed Struggled to Stay Alive, Indictment Says
item.description: Muhammad Abu Khdeir, 16, who was kidnapped this month in Jerusalem, fought his three attackers before being kicked in the head and bludgeoned with a wrench, charging documents said.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: The 29-year-old Israeli suspect left the courtroom on Thursday in Jerusalem.

item.title: Malaysia Airlines Plane With 295 Aboard Crashes in Ukraine
item.description: The plane crashed in eastern Ukraine near the Russian border, and Ukrainian officials said a Russian-made antiaircraft system may have shot it down.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR, DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: An armed pro-Russian separatist at the site of a Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777 plane crash on Thursday in the Donetsk region of Ukraine.

item.title: Afghanistan Begins Audit of Presidential Election
item.description: The audit of almost eight million ballots is part of a deal brokered by Secretary of State John Kerry to ease a dispute between the two candidates.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Britain Urged to Live Up to Responsibilities in Hong Kong
item.description: Two of Hong Kong’s most prominent democracy activists, Anson Chan and Martin Lee, raised their concerns about Chinese rule before a British parliamentary committee this week.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Martin Lee, right, a founder of the Democracy Party, who spoke before a British parliamentary committee this week, joined Cardinal Joseph Zen, center, the former head of the Roman Catholic Church in Hong Kong, and others in a walk for universal suffrage on June 14.

item.title: Inquiry Faults Assurances to Potential Terror Suspects in Ireland
item.description: A government program to inform some potential terror suspects that they did not face arrest was “flawed” but was not an amnesty, a report said.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Gerry Adams, the leader of Sinn Fein, after he was released in May without charge.

item.title: Malaysia Airlines Jet Missing Over Ukraine
item.description: Malaysia Airlines reported losing contact with an Amsterdam-Kulala Lumpur flight over Ukraine. A Russian news agency reported it had been shot down.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Boys Drawn to Gaza Beach, and Into Center of Mideast Strife
item.description: Two explosions struck an area that had been considered relatively safe from the intense Israeli bombing campaign.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: The aftermath of an airstrike on a beach in Gaza City on Wednesday. Four young Palestinian boys, all cousins, were killed.
